Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Ellen S. Chih is "Definable Sets and Structures." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Wisconsin-Madison, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Steffen Lempp.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal is focused on studying definability and the complexity of definable objects in mathematics as calibrated by computability theory. For example, sets in the Arithmetic and Borel hierarchies, such as the computably enumerable (c.e.) sets, are among the definable objects investigated. One main project is to study the global structure of the c.e. degrees and c.e. sets. This project is related to the Bi-interpretability Conjecture, which relates the structure of the c.e. degrees to first order arithmetic. This project aims to approach this conjecture by investigating the automorphism group of the c.e. degrees and the definability of jump classes in the c.e. degrees. If the Bi-interpretability Conjecture is true, it would provide a complete logical characterization of the structure of the c.e. degrees in terms of first order arithmetic and it would have many consequences for computability theory. For example, one such consequence would be the rigidity of the c.e. degrees. The proposed investigation aims to provide positive evidence and develop new technology for the Bi-interpretability Conjecture. Difficulties in this endeavor will possibly illuminate methods of building a nontrivial automorphism of the c.e. degrees and bring in a new perspective for the c.e. degrees. The proposed investigation on c.e. sets would clarify the relationship between jump classes and isomorphisms of the lattice of c.e. sets.

The second project is to study uncountable structures by investigating structures with a Borel representation. This project aims to investigate the effective version of the Scott set problem, which involves Borel structures. The Scott set problem asks whether every Scott set is exactly the set of standard parts of nonstandard elements of some nonstandard model of arithmetic. The Scott set problem is a longstanding open question in an interesting situation where any progress on the effective version of the question would be informative. The proposed research aims to approach the effective version by building Borel Scott sets that are not jump ideals.The only known examples of Borel Scott sets are jump ideals. Part of this proposed project is involved with illuminating other questions in the same situation by investigating the effective versions.

There are no project outcomes or findings to report as defined in the NSF review criteria. Family issues prevented the use of this award.


Last Modified: 09/04/2015
Modified by: Ellen S Chih
